channel.title: Jar files won't run
channel.description: every jar file i want to open close directly. is it my java or something else?

item.title: Jar files won't run
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:15, topic:546180”][quote author=The Web Guy link=topic=665076.msg4447002#msg4447002 date=1409337577]

If you clearly read my initial post, it has “pause” added to the end… He never complained about the batch file closing immediately…

Because he couldn’t get it to open in the first place.
I didn’t add the pause in because I forgot.

So why do I need to “pls stahp” …
[/quote]
Because you’re trying to help people (not saying it’s wrong to help others) but it looks like you only have so much advice or actual help…

Your problem: The JAR file opens and closes immediately.
My Suggestion: Use a batch file to help better understand the errors.
The purpose of the batch file: The purpose is not to run the JAR successfully, but for when it opens and closes, log why it closes instantly. In the batch file after the JAR immediately closes, you will get clues as to why it’s doing so. Use the batch file to try running the JAR, when the JAR closes, post a screen shot of the batch file here, that’s all I’m asking you to do.

^This is my proof lol. His problem isn’t the JAR opening and closing instantly, that is a result from the problem.
Your suggestion also sounds a bit misleading. The .batch file is to debug the errors. Not “understand them”.
And the purpose of the batch file, is like I said, it’s to debug.[/quote]

The purpose of debugging is to understand what’s wrong, correct? Or am I completely missing something…
And yes, the problem that he is having, which is why he made this thread, is that the JAR is opening and closing. It goes two ways.

Take a car that suddenly stops running, that’s a problem for someone, correct? Yes.
However, the problem is that the battery is dead.

A problem can be viewed multiple ways. In my instance, he is having a problem because he can’t open the JAR successfully, and yes, the JAR has its own specific problem.

He is trying to understand what is wrong, and why he is having problems opening the JAR file. He can do so by using the [i]batch file[i] to debug and get a better [i]understand[i]ing… Ffs. If you still don’t understand it you’re SOL.

Read full topic

Your suggestion also sounds a bit misleading. The .batch file is to debug the errors. Not “understand them”.
And the purpose of the batch file, is like I said, it’s to debug.

item.title: Jar files won't run
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:13, topic:546180”][quote author=The Web Guy link=topic=665076.msg4446998#msg4446998 date=1409337456]

[quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=665076.msg4446997#msg4446997 date=1409337233]

[quote author=maul ownz link=topic=665076.msg4446960#msg4446960 date=1409308046]

You forgot to add java.exe to the path…
Use this CMD code:

@echo off
"C:\Program Files\Java\jre7\bin\java.exe" -jar client1.jar

Or even:

@echo off
java -jar client1.jar

[/quote]it opens but not the java file only the batch.
i can’t make a webclient with the batch
[/quote]Okay
Add
"pause" on the last line.
Post whatever error comes up.

Alright, let me lay this out a little better.

Your problem: The JAR file opens and closes immediately.
My Suggestion: Use a batch file to help better understand the errors.
The purpose of the batch file: The purpose is not to run the JAR successfully, but for when it opens and closes, log why it closes instantly. In the batch file after the JAR immediately closes, you will get clues as to why it’s doing so. Use the batch file to try running the JAR, when the JAR closes, post a screen shot of the batch file here, that’s all I’m asking you to do. [/quote]
Pls stahp… The batch file closing instantly makes it almost impossible to actually capture what’s wrong… OP needs to make it so the batch file stops… Aka by adding “pause”…

If you clearly read my initial post, it has “pause” added to the end… He never complained about the batch file closing immediately…

Because he couldn’t get it to open in the first place.
I didn’t add the pause in because I forgot.[/quote]

So why do I need to “pls stahp” …

Read full topic

Alright, let me lay this out a little better.

Your problem: The JAR file opens and closes immediately.

In the batch file after the JAR immediately closes, you will get clues as to why it’s doing so. Use the batch file to try running the JAR, when the JAR closes, post a screen shot of the batch file here, that’s all I’m asking you to do. [/quote]

If you clearly read my initial post, it has “pause” added to the end… He never complained about the batch file closing immediately…

item.title: Jar files won't run
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

[quote=“maul ownz, post:4, topic:546180”][quote author=The Web Guy link=topic=665076.msg4446741#msg4446741 date=1409227664]

If you already have the latest version of java and its in the right directory.

it may be your environmental variables.

ill be glad to fix this for you, and teach you how environmental variables work if needed.

It shouldn’t be the environmental variables…

So that we can better assist you, run the JAR through command prompt, here are some steps for that.

[ol][li]Create a new batch file in the same directory as your JAR.[/li]
[li]Edit the .bat file and paste this code into it, then customize your code.[/li][/ol]

@echo on
C:\PATH_TO_JAVA_INSTALLATION\ -jar JAR_NAME.jar
pause

Replace PATH_TO_JAVA_INSTALLATION with the path to your Java installation (should look something like this: C:\Program Files (x86)\Java\jre7\bin) and replace JAR_NAME with the name of your JAR file, for example: client.jar

This may or may not start the JAR (probably not) but it will give you errors in command prompt that you can work with. Post those errors so that we can help you figure out what’s wrong.
[/quote]I don’t get it all, I need someone who helps me on teamviewer[/quote]

No, you don’t need someone to help you through Teamviewer, you want someone who helps you through Teamviewer. You’re not going to be spoonfed your entire life, I gave you pretty clear instructions on how to troubleshoot. Launch the JAR using the BAT file and take note of what errors you get while doing so, then, post them here and I’ll be glad to continue helping.

Read full topic

item.title: Jar files won't run

So that we can better assist you, run the JAR through command prompt, here are some steps for that.

[ol][li]Create a new batch file in the same directory as your JAR.[/li]
[li]Edit the .bat file and paste this code into it, then customize your code.[/li][/ol]

@echo on
C:\PATH_TO_JAVA_INSTALLATION\ -jar JAR_NAME.jar
pause

Replace PATH_TO_JAVA_INSTALLATION with the path to your Java installation (should look something like this: C:\Program Files (x86)\Java\jre7\bin) and replace JAR_NAME with the name of your JAR file, for example: client.jar

This may or may not start the JAR (probably not) but it will give you errors in command prompt that you can work with. Post those errors so that we can help you figure out what’s wrong.[/quote]I don’t get it all, I need someone who helps me on teamviewer

Read full topic
